text: For an industry that needs to move fast and work nimbly,

the post-production workflow can spend a surprising amount
of time waiting on manual file transfers,
hard drives for media to ship out to editors,
and redundant operational tasks.

With a Cloud-based workflow, automated processes reduce
much of the overhead in the pipeline,
allowing work to get done faster

and collaborators and talent from all over the
world to have easier input into the project.

Join us as we go all in on how adopters
are breaking barriers

and reshaping the future of the post-production
industry with “Studio in the Cloud.”

To give us a better sense of how this end-to-end
cloud-based pipeline is achievable,
I spoke with “Race to the Cloud” director and editor Katrina King
on how this experience is changing the editing process.

Can you tell me about the post-production
process that you used for “Race to the Cloud”?
Well, “Race to the Cloud” was posted entirely in the cloud on AWS,
which is starting to become the norm.

How we did it was we started with the Unreal projects
that were used in previsualization and in production

to create all of the cinematic pass by shots you see
of the cars passing by and things like that.
Everything was edited in Premiere, running on an EC2 instance,
and then we did all of the color correction using FilmLight's Baselight system

connected to our color
in the cloud pipeline

that won the HPA Engineering
Excellence Award in 2022,

and then finally we did our
QC in Colorfront.

A couple of years ago
there were almost no way

to connect a reference
monitor to a remote instance
for cloud-based post-production.

On “Race to the Cloud” I think we had three or maybe
even four different ways of doing it.
We had the color in the cloud pipeline connected to Baselight,
we had the Colorfront streaming server connected to Colorfront,
we had a Streambox integration with Adobe Premiere,
and then we use the Blackmagic DeckLink system for our Fairlight audio post.
After editing comes color correction.

To talk about how a cloud-based workflow is streamlining
the color and post-production process as a whole,
I sat down with Managing Director of FilmLight, Peter Postma.

Can you tell me a little bit about the AWS services
that are part of your architecture?
Yeah, to deliver a color correction that the artist wants,

which is very interactive, we really tied
together a lot of the Amazon services.

So the core Baselight software is running on an
Amazon EC2 instance with GPUs
because all our image rendering is done on the GPUs, they can be very fast.
It also needs high speed storage.
So we're using either FSx Lustre Storage or Weka Storage
to deliver those high data rates of uncompressed high resolution footage,
and then the artist also needs an image they can depend

as their reference image when they're color grading,
when they're making their color decisions,

they need to make sure that there's no
compression artifacts or things like that
that are, you know, biasing what they're seeing.

So we partnered with Amazon
on their CDI technology

to stream uncompressed images
out of the EC2 instance

and then into the
Elemental MediaConnect service

to actually do the JPEG XS compression
and stream that to the client at the end.

So as the “Race to the Cloud” production came together, what were some
of the key benefits that you saw as FilmLight as being part of that?
Yeah, the biggest benefit was just having everyone on that shared storage
so that the VFX, editorial, and us in color were all pulling from the same place.
So when we needed to have a VFX shot updated,

we didn't then have to wait for someone to deliver it
in a hard drive or send a download link,

it was just right there where it needed to be
and we could conform off of it right away.

So just that speed of interaction with all the other departments
was really the biggest benefit.

The final step of the post-production process is quality control
monitoring and the creation of a “master” project file.

Colorfront is on the forefront of using the cloud for brand-new
processes like virtual QCing and Mastering.

Director of Solution Engineering Brandon Heaslip
shared more with me about Colorfront’s exciting advancements.

So, tell me a little bit about what the architecture looks like for
Colorfront when they're using cloud.
So our architecture is actually pretty simple.
All the security on the sense of how the systems are accessed, etcetera,
is done by the studio or the customer.

For us, we require a
G5 12x large instance,
obviously inside a secure VPC,

there's some networking
side of things
in order to say remote desktop into the system,
whether you're using NICE DCV or Teradici or your choice,
that's all up to you and your security team and users,

and then for the reference quality stream
that comes out of QC Player,

that's just allowing a couple of ports
to be opened for both the video to actually leave,
that's the biggest thing is to get it out of the cloud,
and obviously we need read and list access to an S3 bucket.

So, when it comes down to it, it's an instance and an S3 bucket
and you can start streaming.

And so how is that different for somebody
that's doing QC? What do they notice?
Is there anything that is different when they're using the cloud,
or is their experience really kind of hidden from them?
Ideally it’s hidden from them.

Ideally, you know, a QC operator would log into the machine,
they'd log in with their Active Directory user,
they'd launch the software, get into their work order system on prem.
It should work exactly the same in the cloud,

and so there's a lot of automated tools that you can do
in the sense of routing the video

when you launch the session for the operator to make it feel like
they're operating the machine,
whether it's, you know, in the machine room or in the cloud

and I think that's one of the biggest things that they,
everyone is kind of striving towards,

because there still is a little bit of a not quite there yet,
but we're not too far away.
What are end customers putting on as

kind of constraints or pressures that are making the QC process
in the cloud the most efficient way to go?
I think it's turnaround time.
I think when you have facilities all over the world

with some of our major partners,
you might be doing a job in London

and they finish the job really, really late at night,
the London QC team has been taken offline,

but all the media is in the London region or in Frankfurt,
wherever the, you know, it needs to be.

But their office in Burbank is just coming online and that needs
to be turned around by the end of day, say in 6 hours.
Well, do you keep the London operator on over time?
They're already tired, they've already spent a long day QCing things.

Or do you get one of the team in Burbank
to say, pick up the job and run with it?
But they don't have to move the media.
They just light up the room, assign it, spin up the machine,

and they can immediately start QCing with that same reference
quality, you know, as they were seeing in London.
They’ll of course speed up the workflow.

Then it's done and then they say, okay,
it's delivered or it needs to be fixed,

and then the work and then the process
continues as quickly as possible.
What Filmlight and Colorfront have achieved

is just the beginning of how the
cloud can make post-production more efficient.

Wide-spread adoption of these processes
minimize repetitive tasks
and allow filmmakers to do what they do best:

focus on crafting compelling art and
narratives with a distinctive point of view.
